newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: SOCCER-CLOUDS SHROUD CZECH FRYDEK'S LEVERKUSEN TRANSFER.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-CLOUDS SHROUD CZECH FRYDEK'S LEVERKUSEN TRANSFER.

text.p: The transfer of Sparta Prague midfielder Martin Frydek to Germany's Bayern Leverkusen, which appeared to be signed last week, has fallen under a cloud of confusion after Sparta officials denied the move had been finalised.
Last week, the two teams appeared to reach an agreement on the transfer, reported to be worth some 1.2 million marks.

But Czech international Frydek said on Tuesday that the chances of his moving to the German club have dimmed greatly after Sparta's Slovak-led management team said two signatures of board members were needed in order to approve the transfer.

"I am very upset, I don't know what conditions complicated the situation, maybe financial ones. Right now, I see my chances at leaving for Leverkusen at about 50-50," Frydek was quoted as saying in the daily Sport.
Frydek's agent Zdenek Nehoda said he was shown a signed contract between Bayern Leverkusen and Sparta, signed by its General Manager Gejza Sestak and his German counterpart.
Sparta President Milan Valasik, however, told Sport that under conditions set out within the club, two board members must sign agreements concerning player transfers.
"Sestak of course has the right to sign, but his signature alone is not enough," Valasik said.
"My personal opinion is that the amount Leverkusen is offering is inadequate," he added though he would not comment on the amount Sparta was offered, or seeking for Frydek.
Sparta, which won its 23rd first division title this year, was bought by Slovak steel group VSZ last year, which promptly changed the club's leadership.
Frydek was a frequent subsitute for the upstart Czechs during the Euro 96 campaign, which saw the team reach the final before losing to Germany on a "golden goal" in sudden-death extra-time.
